stream_context.summary: In a bonus stream, Kaze worked on a desert town level for 'Return to Yoshi's Island.' The main activities included debugging and fixing a completely broken vanilla Pokey enemy, confronting and solving a critical out-of-RAM issue by cutting a planned level section, adding NPCs to make the town feel more alive, and placing coins. The stream heavily featured technical problem-solving and pragmatic design decisions driven by the N64's hardware limitations.

development_findings.summary: To manage RAM limitations, the team is using NPC dialogue about stolen goods as a narrative trick to avoid modeling and loading assets for shops.
development_findings.quote: This is a trick we do so we don't actually have to 3D model the stuff here because we are getting pretty close to running out of RAM.

development_findings.summary: A significant technical constraint of the SM64 decompilation project is the difficulty in loading assets on a per-area basis, leading to the entire level's data being loaded at once and causing memory issues.
development_findings.quote: In D-Comp, it's so hard to just have data per area, you know?

development_findings.summary: Due to severe RAM limitations in the desert level, Kaze made the decision to cut an entire section called the 'Yoshi Ranch' to make the level playable.
development_findings.quote: Honestly, I'm fine with cutting out the Yoshi Ranch. I think that was unnecessary fluff anyway.

development_findings.summary: Kaze implemented a workaround for armature translations by mathematically representing them as a pair of rotations, avoiding the need for full translation support in the engine.
development_findings.quote: No, this is actually just me cheating... You can represent any translation as a combination of two rotations.

development_findings.summary: Kaze debugged a lighting issue where a model appeared to be glowing by discovering its alpha channel was incorrect. He fixed it by multiplying the color with a bit of blue.

Kaze is actively adding NPCs with unique dialogue to the desert town to make the level feel more alive and to provide narrative hints, such as a character who implies the trains are dangerous obstacles.
development_findings.quote: I think that's very fitting. But I'm trying to make this that will look a little more alive because right now it feels like there isn't too many NPCs here.

development_findings.summary: The game uses a more precise algorithm for generating random rotations compared to the original SM64. This makes every randomly rotated object, like a tumbleweed, unique, which could theoretically be used to detect cheated speedruns.
development_findings.quote: In this game, every rotation is unique, because we actually use a signed approximation algorithm instead of a rounded lot.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is cynical about game jam competitions, believing they reward 'playing to the audience' over quality. He feels that extending deadlines after a contest has started is unfair to participants who followed the original rules.
context_findings.quote: It's like you altering the deal after you've made the deal, you know, like what Unity did.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds the opinion that successful game designers continue to design games, implying that those who teach it may not have been as successful in the industry.
context_findings.quote: Who would go to a school to teach game design? It would have to be someone who wasn't as successful as a game designer, right?

context_findings.summary: Kaze dislikes idioms and overly descriptive language, preferring communication that is direct and clear in its intent.
context_findings.quote: I value language that is concise and precise. So if you just add on things, they tend to just make it worse for me.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a strong dislike for 2D platformers and most boss fights, stating he finds them boring or only good for spectacle rather than gameplay. His taste in games is very specific.
context_findings.quote: You guys need to realize I hate games. When you say you would love this game, I always thinking where this guy doesn't know me at all.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is experiencing significant issues with PayPal, which has frozen his account for months, preventing him from receiving donations correctly. This is a direct financial impact on his streaming.

When asked about ownership of the game engine code, Kaze acknowledges the ambiguity, comparing it to the 'Ship of Theseus' paradox where it's hard to determine if the modified code is still Nintendo's or has become his own creation.
context_findings.quote: That's kind of like an arbitrary line at some point, right? It's the ship of the size meme.

biobak.summary: Kaze jokingly called out Biobak regarding a texture that wasn't receiving lighting correctly, indicating a collaborative and informal team dynamic.
biobak.quote: Why, Biobak? Why? Why would you do this to us?

biobak.summary: Biobak is working on a node-based lighting system. Kaze discussed the implementation, suggesting he prefers to use it as an additive layer for experimentation rather than a mandatory base layer.

badub.summary: Kaze praises Badub's music for creatively using the original Mario 64 soundfont to create a soundtrack that feels completely new yet maintains a similar vibe to the original.
badub.quote: It's freaking amazing like how different from the default Mario 64 sound. Most of it is still the default Mario 64 sound font... but they're used in really creative ways.

zeina.summary: Kaze identified a need for animations for the newly implemented Pokey enemy and stated he would ask Zeina to create them.
In addition to animation, Zeina appears to be responsible for creating some 3D models and environmental assets, such as a 'tumbleweed store' for the level.
zeina.quote: I gotta ask Zeina to make a tumbleweed store here.

key_stories.title: The RAM Crisis and Cutting the Yoshi Ranch
key_stories.summary: Faced with critical RAM limitations in a large desert level, Kaze was forced to make a significant design cut. He removed an entire planned area, the 'Yoshi Ranch,' to ensure the level would run on the N64 hardware, highlighting the harsh technical realities of the project.
key_stories.challenge: A complex desert level with 40,000 triangles was exceeding the N64's RAM limits, causing the game to crash upon loading. The decompilation project's structure made it difficult to load assets dynamically per area.
key_stories.process: After the level failed to load, Kaze confirmed the high triangle count. Recognizing the difficulty of implementing per-area loading, he identified the 'Yoshi Ranch' as non-essential 'fluff' and decided to remove it entirely. He later found other minor optimizations but the area cut was the major solution.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze made the pragmatic decision to cut an entire planned section of the level, the 'Yoshi Ranch'. This solved the immediate memory crisis and allowed development on the core area to continue, demonstrating a willingness to sacrifice content for performance.
key_stories.key_quote: We're actually this much out of RAM. That is insane, actually. [...] All right, let's cut the Yoshi Ranch then, I guess.

key_stories.title: Resurrecting the Broken Pokey
key_stories.summary: An optimization in Kaze's custom engine unexpectedly broke the behavior of the vanilla Pokey enemy, leading to a deep and frustrating debugging session. The solution revealed a fundamental conflict between modern optimization techniques and the assumptions of the original 25-year-old code, but ultimately resulted in a working enemy with new visual enhancements.
key_stories.challenge: The standard Pokey enemy from Mario 64 was completely broken in the new engine. Its body segments would either fail to appear or spawn high in the air before vanishing.
key_stories.process: Kaze undertook a lengthy debugging process, using console logs and stubbing out code. He discovered the root cause was an optimization in his engine that prevented non-moving objects from doing floor checks. Since Pokey segments are moved by a parent object rather than their own velocity, they weren't finding the ground. After disabling this optimization for the Pokey, he fixed further bugs related to scaling and model orientation to restore full functionality.
key_stories.outcome: The Pokey was successfully fixed and implemented. Kaze's fix also led to an improvement: the enemy's shadow now becomes more transparent as it loses body segments, a visual flourish not present in the original.
key_stories.key_quote: My engine made it so that if an object doesn't move it doesn't Raycast the floor every tick. But they needed the floor to be Raycasted every tick. So I just removed that requirement basically.
